Award.AwardTitle: Conference on the Foundations of Computational Mathematics 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Conference on the Foundations of Computational Mathematics 2017 is the ninth of a successful series and will be held in Barcelona, Spain from July 10 to July 19, 2017. This award funds the attendance at the meeting of at least twenty junior U.S. participants, including graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early career tenure track faculty. The conference features seventeen plenary speakers, eight of whom are from the US, and 21 workshops where the junior participants participants will be able to present a talk or a poster.

The impact of constantly increasing computational power has changed the relationship between mathematics and computation. New applications such as encryption, large scale data management, and signal/image processing, inevitably led to the study of the computational tools themselves, creating and reinvigorating a rich spectrum of mathematical disciplines. Mathematicians now increasingly recognize that, besides its value as a numerical and experimental tool, computation is a significant theoretical tool in its own right. This conference aims to further the understanding of the connections between mathematics and computation, including the interfaces between pure and applied mathematics, numerical analysis and computer science. This is reflected in the diverse and vibrant research areas covered by the 21 workshops which are organized by world experts, including many from the US. This award is instrumental in enabling the participation of many US young researchers at this renowned and exciting conference.

Conference website: http://www.ub.edu/focm2017/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Besides its value as a numerical and experimental tool, computation is now recognized as a significant theoretical instrument, an important object of mathematical study, and an exciting source of new mathematical problems. The Foundations of Computational Mathematics (FoCM) conference series aims to further the understanding of the connections between mathematics and computation, including the interfaces between pure and applied mathematics, numerical analysis and computer science.
This grant provided partial support for 19 junior US researchers without funding (graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, and tenure-track faculty) to attend the conference FoCM'17 in Barcelona, Spain, on July 10-19, 2017, and present their work (either talks or posters). Moreover, the grant helped cover partially the expenses of 3 unsupported US-based senior researchers; two of them were plenary speakers and the other one a workshop organizer. In their written feedback, junior participants praised the organization and quality of FoCM'17, indicated the positive impact that this experience had in their careers, and were thankful to the NSF for this opportunity.
The conference FoCM'17 featured diverse activities such as 18 distinguished plenary lectures, 21 specialized workshops with 36 semi-plenary talks, 71 poster presentations, and informal interactions among participants which synthesize forefront research with mentoring and training opportunities for young participants, thereby helping them develop networks that include the world's leading researchers. Consistent with the tradition of FoCM conferences to welcome and accommodate newcomers into the computational mathematics research community,  the seniority distribution of FoCM'17 was 169 junior participants out of a total of 597 participants.
